awd_titl_txt: Ergodic Theory of Non-Amenable Group Actions
awd_abstract_narration:
Classical dynamics studies how systems change in time. Ergodic theory focuses on the statistical behavior of dynamical systems. Applications of ergodic theory are widespread: from traffic modeling to aerospace engineering and population dynamics. It is natural and of practical importance to generalize the role of time in a dynamical system to more complicated groups of symmetries. This generalized notion of dynamics leads to applications in statistical physics, number theory and geometry. However, new tools are needed especially in the particular case when the group of symmetries is non-amenable which means that boundary phenomena are too significant to be safely ignored. Non-amenable groups naturally arise in many parts of mathematics such as geometry and number theory. This project is concerned with developing the tools needed to analyze the statistical behavior of non-amenable group actions by generalizing ergodic theory to this context. 

The research goals of this project are: 1) Continue developing sofic entropy theory, which is a vast generalization of Kolmogorov-Sinai entropy to actions of sofic groups, a class of groups that contains all amenable groups and residually finite groups. One ambitious goal is to classify the mixing Markov chains over free groups using asymptotic geometric invariants of associated model spaces. 2) Classify sofic approximations of low-dimensional groups (using geometric techniques), with an eye towards using the results to construct the first known non-sofic groups from amalgams of low-dimensional groups. 3) Explore the limits of pointwise ergodic theorems for geometrically defined groups (e.g. Lie groups, CAT(0) cubulated groups, relatively hyperbolic groups) via the measured-equivalence techniques developed by the principal investigator and Nevo and the ideas behind the recent L^1-counterexample of Tao. Also develop new multiplicative ergodic theorems for cocycles taking values in tracial von Neumann algebras. 4) Import tools from geometric group theory into the study of measured equivalence relations (MERs) through the use of metric bundles in place of actions, graphings in place of Cayley graphs and so on. More specific goals include proving analogs of the Tits alternative for MERs and classifying the normal sub-equivalence relations of low-dimensional MERs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Classical dynamics studies how systems change in time. The subfield of ergodic theory focusses on statistical behavior. This project concerns systems in which the role of time has been generalized to more complicated groups of symmetries, with potential applications to statistical physics, number theory and geometry. New tools are needed especially when the group is non-amenable which means that boundary phenomena are too significant to be ignored. Non-amenable groups naturally arise in geometry and number theory. This project is concerned with developing the tools needed to analyze the statistical behavior of these group actions. 

One such tool is that of sofic approximations, where a sofic approximation to a group is a sequence of partial actions on finite sets which approximates the way the group acts on itself. A group which admits a sofic approximation is called sofic. Many non-amenable groups are sofic and sofic approximations allow the import of some techniques from classical ergodic theory. It is a famous open problem whether all groups are sofic. With P. Burton, the PI showed for certain well-studied groups, either there exist exotic sofic approximations or certain explicit constructions yield non-sofic groups. Moreover, with P. Burton the PI extended the soficity notion from discrete groups to locally compact continuous groups. 

In 2009, the PI initiated sofic entropy theory, a generalization of classical entropy theory to actions of sofic groups.  The theory developed quickly but has been difficult for the outsider to penetrate. The PI wrote a comprehensive 100+ page survey article for beginners. Other product include: (1) a paper with D. Airey and Y. F. Lin showing that topological sofic entropy can take on different values depending on the choice of sofic approximation (which cannot happen in classical cases), (2) a paper introducing new sofic invariants which take into account the overall shape of the space of approximations; this was used to build a counterexample to the Weak Pinsker Problem by showing that some actions cannot be decomposed into purely random parts and parts which are almost deterministic, (3) a paper with Y.F. Lin showing that a certain averaged version of sofic entropy is invariant under bounded orbit equivalence, (4) a paper with R. Tucker-Drob showing Weak Pinsker entropy, is invariant under all orbit-equivalences if the group is cocycle-superrigid (a property known to hold for many naturally-occuring non-amenable groups). 

The classic von Neumann-Day problem asked whether every countable non-amenable group contains a rank 2 free subgroup. It was proved false by Olshankii in the 1980s. The analogous question for orbit equivalence relations of non-amenable groups remains open. The PI proved that it is true in the presence of positive entropy. This uses a new theorem of the PI's: that for non-amenable groups, all Bernoulli actions satisfy the measurable von Neumann-Day problem, and a result of B. Seward, that positive entropy implies the existence of a Bernoulli factor.

Birkhoff's classical ergodic theorem states that, if a transformation (often representing time) preserves a measure, then for almost every initial condition, the time averages of an observable converge to the average over the space of configurations. A. Nevo generalized this by replacing the notion of time with semi-simple Lie groups, in the 1990s. These theorems have applications in dynamics and number theory. The PI and A. Nevo obtained new simpler proofs in the hyperbolic case with a greater range in the kinds of averages. With P. Burton, the PI obtained a counterexample when the group is SL(2,R) and the observable is merely integrable. This is quite different from the classical case, where only integrability is needed.

 Oseledet's multiplicative ergodic theorem (MET) is central to smooth dynamics. It provides a picture of the long-term dynamics at the infinitesimal scale. While infinite-dimensional generalizations have been obtained by Ruelle and others, these require  the system to be asymptotically contracting in all but a finite number of dimensions. The PI with B. Hayes and Y.F. Lin obtained the first MET which allows for continuous Lyapunov spectra, by using tracial von Neumann algebras in place of finite-dimensional matrix algebras.

Regarding broader impacts, the PI is the main organizer for UT's new summer DRP (directed reading program) which debuted in 2021. The program pairs around 15 UT graduate students with undergraduates from Texas, many of whom come from under-represented groups, to read advanced topics in mathematics. The PI also organized a week-long graduate mini-school in Groups & Dynamics with around 16 speakers and 20 supported graduate students. The PI mentored an undergraduate (Ryan Chatterjee) through an honors thesis on Selberg's Trace Formula. Ryan is now a graduate student at Northwestern. The PI mentored Y.F. Lin through his PhD (2020). Lin has obtained postdocs at Ben-Gurion and TAMU. The PI mentored P. Burton as a Bing postdoc at UT. The PI is currently mentoring 3 graduate students and two postdocs.
